In 2006, K. joined TYM Fund in order to gain access to financial services so that she can help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. K. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

K. is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND, which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. K. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase seeds, insecticides, fertilizers, chemical products, etc.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena C. is from the village of Dolores, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Nena is married and has two school-aged children. Nena runs a "sari-sari" or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products such as soap, shampoo, toothpaste, etc., in the local community. Nena has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Nena joined GDMPC, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Nena is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell to expand her product offering. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Nena from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell to expand her product offering

loans.name: Wipala Jóvenes Group

texts.es: “Wipala Jóvenes” es un grupo de cuatro integrantes, de los cuales dos se dedican a la venta de productos medicinales naturales, tales como yerbas, semillas y plantas, uno  se dedica a la  costura de diferentes prendas de vestir, especializándose en deportivos y uno a vender productos varios  según la temporada o época. Todos necesitan el préstamo para la compra de mercadería y materia prima.
texts.en:
“Wipala Jóvenes” is a 4-member group. One of the group members sells natural medicinal products, such as herbs, seeds, and plants. Another member sews different types of garments, specializing in sportswear, and another member sells seasonal products. All of the group members need the loan for the purchase of merchandise and raw material.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and raw material

loans.name: Ana Virginia

texts.es: Doña virginia es originaria de la comunidad de Totonicapan  su actividad economica es la marraneria viene ejerciendo dicha actividad cuando tenia catorce años, sus principales puntos de ventas son San cristobal Toto los dias Domingos, sabados y martes en la ciudad de Totonicapan y los dias jueves Salcaja Quetzaltenango en la venta de chicharrones de marrano y sus derivados hoy necesita de un credito por la sencilla razon en busca de otros mercados principalmente momostenango en la plaza de los dias jueves con la utilidad le permite satisfacer la necesidad de su familia.
texts.en:
Doña Virginia is originally from the community of Totonicapan. She operates a pig farm, which she first learned to do when she was 14 years old. She sells chicharrones (fried pork skins) and other pork products. The primary locations where she sells are San Cristobal Toto on Sundays and Saturdays, Totonicapan on Tuesdays, and Salcaja Quetzaltenango on Thursdays.

She needs a loan for the simple reason of opening new markets, primarily in Momostenago Square on Thursdays. She hopes this will meet the needs of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase operating capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth sells meals every evening from her front porch, putting out four tables beginning around 6:00 pm. She offers her customers fried chicken, hot dogs, french fries, hamburgers, and soft drinks. She has an excellent location for her business, near the corner of a main road, and has a good customer base.

Elizabeth has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner, for two years and is a member of the "Amigas Por Siempre" (Friends Forever) communal bank . Elizabeth invested her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in ingredients for cakes and other baked goods, which she sold at her father’s bakery. Although she was able to earn additional income by working at her father’s bakery, Elizabeth wanted to have her own independent business, so she decided to start her little home-based restaurant. Her business has been going quite well. 

Elizabeth used her last loan of 1500 soles (about $500) from Manuela Ramos to purchase a special fryer for chicken. Elizabeth plans to use this loan of 2000 soles to purchase six more tables, better chairs, and food in bulk. Elizabeth’s business has grown a lot. On weekends, she now has more customers than she can accommodate at the four tables she has in her restaurant. 

Elizabeth lives with her partner and their two children, ages 13 and 7. Her partner works as a supervisor at a company that repairs broken phone lines and downed phone systems. 

Elizabeth is glad to be working with Manuela Ramos. She was unable to get loans from other banks because they had too many requirements. Elizabeth also appreciates the educational talks given by Manuela Ramos’s loan officers at every monthly meeting of her communal bank. These talks deal with business-related themes (e.g. how to promote and develop a business) as well as larger themes, such as making life goals, etc. 

Elizabeth "thinks big" about her business and has many goals for the future. Eventually, she wants to buy an extra-large deep fryer for making french fries. She also wants to turn the front room of her home into a restaurant so she will have a larger and more comfortable space for her customers.

In this short video clip, Elizabeth talks about how she wants to expand and improve her business, and how she plans to take full advantage of her loans in order to do so.

loans.use: Higher-quality chairs, six tables, food in bulk for a restaurant business.

loans.name: Pranita

texts.en:
Miss Pranita T. is a single woman who lives in Thikedewol. Thikedewal is located in the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses.
Miss T. has four members, including herself, in her family. Her father's name is Mr. Pratap T., and he is a retired principal. Her older sister is a teacher and younger sister works in a beauty parlor.
Miss T. started the beauty salon with the help of her first kiva loan. The most popular services at Pranita’s beauty clinic are threading (a different method of removing hair to waxing) and facials. She took 6 months of training for the work.
Now she is requesting for Rs 15000.00 loan to buys different types of make-up tools for her business.

loans.use: to buys make-up tools

loans.name: Sallebelle

texts.en: Sallebelle R. is from the village of Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old, is married, and has two infant children. Sallebelle owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Sallebelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda M. is from the village of Poblacion 1 , Clarin,Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Gilda is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Gilda owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gilda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gilda is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Gilda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business . 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Séraphine

texts.fr: H. Séraphine est née en 1979 et vit depuis sept ans à Cadjèhoun un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HAGNONNOU Bienvenu, Séraphine est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Séraphine n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école. C’est pourquoi, pour contribuer aux charges de la famille et satisfaire ses besoins quotidiens, Séraphine vend des fruits (bananes, ananas, etc.), et des divers (farine de manioc, galettes d’arachide, etc.) à son domicile au quartier Cadjèhoun. Séraphine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et au marché Dogbo au Bénin. Séraphine a déjà six ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a eu déjà trois crédits et a bien remboursé. Pour mieux satisfaire la demande des clients et réaliser plus d’économies, Séraphine sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.  Séraphine envisage plus tard acheter et construire sa propre parcelle.
texts.en:
Séraphine H. was born in 1979 and has lived for seven years in Cadjèhoun, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Bienvenu Hagnonnou, Séraphine is the mother of two children who all attend school. The couple jointy support their family's needs. Séraphine did not have the opportunity to attend school. And so, to help contribute to family income and to satisfy their daily needs, Séraphine sells fruits (bananas, pineapples, etc.) and diverse food products ( manioc flour, peanut-based cookies etc.) from her home. Séraphine buys her provisions in Dantokpa, an international market in Benin and at the Dogbo market, also in Benin. Séraphine already has six years of experience. She is a former client of ALID from whom she recieved and repayed 3 loans. To better satisfy her customer demand and to see greater savings, Séraphine is asking for a fourth loan. One day she hopes to purchase and construct her own business site.

Translated from French by Kristin Connor, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits (bananas, plantains, oranges, pineapples) and other diverse products (manioc flour, sugar packets, peanut-based cookies)

loans.name: Yomeba

texts.en:
Yomeba C. sells maize flour and onions. She requests a loan to stock beans and rice to sell. Yomeba is 32 years old and is married to a peasant. She has seven children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Jeneffer

texts.en:
Jeneffer C. is from the village of Bayabay within Barangay Panalsalan in Misamis Occidental Province, Mindanao. She is 25 years old, married and has one infant. Jeneffer sells fish to the local community. She has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jeneffer joined GDMPC to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC which she will use to purchase more fish to sell. She plans to use any additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk

loans.name: Fidelina Caceres

texts.en: Fidelina Caceres G., 49, is married to Mr. Juan R. Ortiz. They started a small business selling consumer products 20 years ago and have made enough money to raise their daughter and give her the opportunity to pursue a university degree. Fidelina hopes her daughter will be able to finish university, with their support, and have a good career and future. Fidelina's business is located next to an autoservice station, so she has a steady flow of customers. She and her husband sell their merchandise at a good price and work to provide their clientele with good quality and convenience. They will invest their loan in purchasing more merchandise as the summer holiday season has started and it is a very busy time for business.

loans.use: Merchandise.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie is a 47-year-old widow living with her three children. After the death of her husband, she opened a lingerie and clothing shop in her town in order to raise her family and to pay for her children's schooling. Today, Marie is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy additional merchandise for her clients to purchase.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom M., 66, is married and lives with his three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. M. is in the agriculture sector and grows vegetables, earning an income of $1 USD per day. He has been in this business since 2005. His wife sells sticky rice, earning $3 USD per day. The family is also assisted by his three children who are workers at a garment factory. 

M. and his family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family.  They are seeking to improve their businesses as well as to help with the daily necessary expenses. Therefore, M. is requesting for loan of US $1000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. He wants to use the loan to buy more sticky rice to stock for sale. This is his second loan from CREDIT. (M. is pictured with her husband)

loans.use: buy more sticky rice to stock for sale

loans.name: Melvin Leonel

texts.es:
El Señor Melvin Maleaños C., Labora como Vigilante en el Mercado Roberto Huembés de Managua.
 El tiene tres  hijos a su cargo, y estos se  encuentran en  edad escolar, esta casado, ha trabajado  créditos con CEPRODEL durante cinco año, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido cinco créditos en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL,  el es un cliente excelente.
El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción como: cemento, arena y cerámica para su casa de habitación ya que esta actualmente es de tierra.
Con el objetivo de Brindarles mayor seguridad y una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mr. Melvin Maliaño C. works as a security guard in the Roberto Huembés de Managua Market. He is married and has three school-aged children living at home. For the past five years he has received loans from CEPRODEL. He has used the money, thanks to CEPRODEL, to improve the home where he lives. He is an excellent customer. The money that he is asking for is to buy construction materials such as: cement, sand and ceramic tile for his house: it is currently made out of mud. He is doing this to be able to give his children a safer and better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To improve and enlarge his house

loans.name: Stewart

texts.en: Stewart L. is from the village of Sugarland, Valencia Bukidnon. He is 26 years old. Stewart is married. To make a living, Stewart owns & operates a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling used clothing or ukay ukay, aside from that Stewart owns a motorcycle for transportation services in the local community. Stewart has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $108 US) for these activities. He is shown with his wife in the photo. In 2009, Stewart joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business. Stewart has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Stewart is requesting a second loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: God's Blessing Group

texts.en:
Comfort J. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God’s Blessing.  She is 41 years old, married, and has five children whose educational levels range from elementary school to college student. Comfort herself is a junior high school graduate.

For seven years, Comfort has been selling dry goods from a table at the Red Light Market, which is Liberia's largest market and is on the outskirts of the capital Liberia. She says sells good products in a friendly manner which keeps her customers returning.

Comfort plans to use her 11,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 55,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more dry goods, such as rice, cooking oil, candles, and soap. Her goal is to grow her business to a freestanding shop, and to improve her family's living condition.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Comfort is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more general foodstuffs and household products for a dry goods store.

loans.name: Rang

texts.en: Rang N., aged 31, is married and resides with his children in Takeo province, Cambodia. He has three children, one of whom is sent to a local primary school. He and his wife are engaged in the business of selling hand-made brooms, earning an income of USD 4 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Their standard of living has improved since Rang N. has had this business. He is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a motorbike to transport his brooms to sell. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Marisol Genoveva

texts.es: Marisol Genoveva tiene 37 años, Marisol tiene 2 hijos a su cargo. Esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos. Su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general por lo que ofrece diferentes productos, hace mas de 8 años que se dedica a esta actividad, pues también tiene un trabajo extra de impulsadora en la empresa DISEGSA ya que cuenta con los ingresos fijos de este empleo es así que ella sufraga los gastos del hogar. Actualmente este financiamiento lo realiza para la compra de materia prima. Su deseo es llegar a tener un negocio establecido.
texts.en:
Marisol Genoveve is a 37-year-old woman with two children. This is not her first financing round. For eight years, Marisol has been selling general merchandise, offering a variety of products. In addition, she also works as a sales promoter for a company named DISEGSA. With the help of steady income provided by this job, Marisol is able to cover her household expenses. Currently, she is asking for a loan in order to purchase raw materials. Her wish is to develop an established business.

Translated from Spanish by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa L. is from the village of Quezon, Bukidnon Province. She is 51 years old. Narcisa is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Narcisa owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Narcisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Narcisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narcisa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be Narcisa's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Mir Habib

texts.en:
Mir Habib, son of S. J., lives in the 12th district, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 52, married with five children, two sons and three daughters. Both his sons are college students and he is helped mostly by his elder son. His daughters are school students.

Mir Habib is a very hard-working man and is responsible for paying all the house expenses. He works seven days a week in his retail shop where he sells different kinds of products to earn money. He has requested an individual loan to purchase more stocks such as eggs, beverages and sanitary products to sell. He hopes to expand his business and to be the most popular business dealer.

loans.use: To purchase eggs, beverages and sanitary products to sell

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima B. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 26 years old, single and has 1 infant. To make a living, Fatima owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Fatima has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Fatima joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fatima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Fatima is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Fatima from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Thel

texts.en: Thel C., 41, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. C. is a farmer and sells Cambodian traditional cakes for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es: Oscar C. E., tiene la edad de 42 años, está casado, y vive con su esposa y sus 3 hijos que son su mayor prioridad. Ellos tienen 22, 20 y 11 años de edad. El crédito lo quiere para asistir su finca, específicamente para el cultivo de café, chile y tomate, la idea es comprar el abono, fertilizantes y pagar mano de obra para la siembra de estos cultivos. Desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento a los cultivos para lograr una mejor calidad y para obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando sea tiempo de cosecha. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Oscar también trabaja desde hace muchos años en la agricultura. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
Oscar C. E. is 42 years old. He is married and lives with his wife and three children (aged 22, 20, and 11) who are his main priority. He is requesting the loan to help with his farm, specifically for the cultivation of coffee, chili and tomatoes. The purpose of the loan is to buy fertilizer and to hire laborers to sow these crops. He wants to provide his crops with adequate maintenance in order to achieve the best quality and obtain the most income possible at harvest time. This is the first time that he is requesting a loan with FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the easiness of the process. In addition, Don Oscar has worked in agriculture for many years. He hopes the future offers his family a better quality of life and greater economic stability and hopes to be able to continue growing as a person and as a farmer.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Francoletti-Putz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sowing of coffee, chili, and tomato crops

loans.name: Khkn-0132667-001

texts.en:
Huy Sophoin, 45, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its quality palm products. Sophoin is a housewife while her husband is a skillful blacksmith, earning an income of USD 5 per day. 

Sophoin is requesting a loan of USD 200 to purchase more metal to produce axes and knives to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. Sophoin's husband appears in the photograph.

loans.use: to buy more metal to produce axes and knives

loans.name: Bayartogtoh

texts.en:
Bayartogtoh D. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and two-year-old son in Bayanhongor province, central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son goes to a local kindergarten while his wife Naranjargal is currently unemployed and helps him with his business. Bayartogtoh receives a 41,400 MNT per month disability pension.

Bayartogtoh suffered from a hip-joint bone injury when he was young, but it does not affect his wood-products business. He began his business in 2005 after attending a carpentry certificate training course. He owns and manages a ger and his furniture business, supplying his customers’ orders and needs.  He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood and supplies in order to expand his business and keep up with customers’ orders.

Bayartogtoh would like one day to open a small factory in which he can produce even more products with ease.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and supplies

loans.name: Hilda Rosa

texts.es:
La Señora Hilda Rosa López es socia del banco comunal Mujeres en Expansión, vive por un sector muy conocido como es Vizorrey en la ciudad de Cuenca, este sector es parte de la belleza cuencana, al igual que sus ríos, su gente y su gastronomía.
 
Doña Hilda tiene  46 años, es casada  y tiene 4 hijos de 30, 28, 22 y 20 años de edad, todos sus hijos son solteros, trabajan y le ayudan económicamente, dos de sus hijos  estudian en la universidad, su esposo es mecánico de profesión y  labora en su propio taller de mecánica industrial, con el trabajo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.

La Señora. Hilda se dedica a la venta de comida, tiene un puesto en el Terminal terrestre hace 18 años, ella se  levanta  a las 5 a.m. para terminar de  preparar sus productos, los mismos que termina de vender alrededor de las 2 de la tarde, luego  arregla su local y cocina para el día siguiente terminando su trabajo a las 8 de la noche. Hace un mes y medio se dedica a la venta de productos de medicina natural Omnilife,  este crédito es para comprar estos  productos y también para la compra de víveres para su negocio, este es el primer crédito que realiza en la fundación, fue invitada  por su hija quien tambien es miembro del banco comunal por algún tiempo, su meta es crecer en su nuevo negocio de Omnilife.
texts.en:
Hilda Rosa López is a member of the Mujeres de Expansion Community Bank. She lives in a very well-known area, Vizorrey, in the city of Cuenca. This area adds to the beauty of Cuenca; its rivers, its people and its cuisine. Mrs Hilda is 46, married, and has 4 children ages 30, 28, 22 and 20. All of her children are single, work and help her economically. Two of her children are in university. Her husband is a mechanic and works in his own industrial workshop. With their work they have been able to build their own home. Mrs Hilda sells food. She has had a stall in the bus station for 18 years. She gets up at 5 am. to finish making her products, and she finishes selling them around 2 pm. She later organizes her premises and cooks for the next day, finishing her work at 8 pm. For a month and a half she has sold Omnilife natural medicine products. This loan is for the purchase of Omnilife products and also for the purchase of supplies for her business. This is her first loan with the Fundacion. She was invited by her daughter who has been a member of the community bank for some time. Her goal is to expand her new Omnilife business.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of meat, potatoes, rice, vegetables, etc, and Omnilife products.

loans.name: Malo

texts.en:
Malo F. is 58 and married with four children. She plants, harvests and sells taro. Malo has three years of experience in this business. 

In 2010 Malo joined and obtained her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Malo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Malo needs a loan of 1000 talas to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $155 per week) to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase harvesting equipment

loans.name: Noziramo

texts.en:
K. Noziramo is 47 years old. She and her husband have four children. Noziramo is a kindergarten teacher; however, for several years she has been selling clothing for kids. She spends the income from the business on educating her children, as she and her husband are dreaming that their children will move on into higher education. 

Noziramo has been provided with loans by IMON in the past and has proven to be an accurate and reliable client. Today she is requesting 10,000 TJS for purchasing new goods to sell. Noziramo and her children sincerely thank you for your generous heart.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal, palm oil and salt

loans.name: Brak

texts.en: Brak C., 42, is married and lives with her husband in Kandal province. She and her husband work together selling porridge and rice in the local market and are able to make about US$3 of profit every day. This couple has three children who are employed. Brak C. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en:
Jargalsaihan R. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and two adult children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son attends college while his wife sells a variety of Jargalsaihan’s steel and iron products from a rented stall at the Harhorin, one of the main markets in the city.

Jargalsaihan has been working as an ironsmith in his home since 2004. Before starting his iron craft business, he worked as a bookkeeper for a company in Hovd province in 1978 and an electrician for the Tulga company in 1990. Besides his business earnings, the family has several income sources including his wife's monthly pension of 104,000 MNT and his monthly disability pension of 54,000 MNT.

Jargalsaihan is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to increase his working capital for his ironcraft business. In the future he hopes to expand his business by producing more kinds of products. Jargalsaihan says, "I want to continue grow my business, and buy a plot of land and fence for my son who will live on his own soon."

loans.use: To increase his working capital for his iron craft business

loans.name: Jaime

texts.en:
Jaime E., 40 years old, is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is married and has four children aged 10, 8, 5 and 2.  Jaime is a rice farmer.  He and his wife sell their harvest in the local market.  Jaime works hard to be a good husband and father. He makes sure to set aside money for his children's education. 

Jaime joined CEVI to gain access to financial services. He says he is happy for his decision to join CEVI because his loans help his farming business. He is now requesting a loan of Php 14000 to purchase fertilizers and seeds.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Diodate Elizabeth

texts.es:
En el cantón Rocafuerte se  reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal La Unión Hace La Fuerza. Este lugar se lo conoce por sus deliciosos dulces que preparan los lugareños y que son reconocidos en todo el país.

Para la señora Diodate este es su primer ciclo y fue una amiga la que la llevo a que se integraras al Banco Comunal y le gustado mucho por que el grupo la ha recibido muy bien. Tiene 36 años de edad mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual ha procreado tres hijos de 12, 9 y 7 años, todos están en escuela. Su marido es comerciante vende animales.
 
Trabaja en un restaurante en las tardes y noches y en la mañana  se dedica a la cría de gallinas y chanchos los mismos que cuando están grandes los vende por libras o enteros. Muchas veces al igual que su esposo también se ha dedicado al comercio de compra y venta de animales para lo cual acompaña a su esposo a los campos donde compran más barato para luego llevarlos  a los mercados de Portoviejo donde venden sus  animales a un mejor precio.
 
Este crédito es para comprar gallinas criollas y pollos para la cría, sus sueños son tener una casa de hormigón y bien construida.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the 'La Unión Hace La Fuerza' (Unity is Strength) community bank meet in Rocafuerte canton.  This place is known for the delicious sweet treats that its residents prepare and they are well known throughout the country.

This is Diodate's first loan cycle.  One of her friends brought her to join the community bank and she has liked it a lot because the group has made her very welcome.  Diodate is 36 years old and she lives with her common-law husband.  They have three children aged 12, 9 and 7.  All of the children are in school.  Her husband is a salesman.  He sells animals.

Diodate works in a restaurant in the afternoons and evenings.  In the mornings she raises hens and pigs which, when they are grown, she sells whole or by the pound.  Like her husband, she also works in the buying and selling of animals.  She accompanies her husband to the fields where they buy more cheaply and they then take their animals to the markets of Portoviejo where they sell them for a better price.

This loan will be used to buy creole hens and chickens to raise.  Her dreams are to have a well-built, concrete house.

loans.use: To buy creole hens and chickens

loans.name: Jose Rodrigo

texts.es:
José Rodrigo
Asesor: Marta Lucía
Fecha historia: Diciembre 22 de 2010 

José Rodrigo conoce perfectamente el significado de trabajar en la calle, pues desde hace 25 años inició su aventura como emprendedor vendiendo dulces en la calles de Medellín-Colombia como su única opción laboral, pues la falta de oportunidades lo obligaron a subsistir como independiente. 

Aunque José Rodrigo ha sabido sobrevivir en este camino de empresario en las calles que nos es nada fácil, debido a los factores externos como el clima, la competencia y otras adversidades con las que día a día se enfrenta, actualmente este luchador necesita del apoyo económico para adquirir más surtido como dulces, galletas, confites y chicles que son los que le generan sus ganancias para el sustento diario. 

Como un gran visionario, José Rodrigo sueña con tener en el futuro un local propio donde además de vender sus dulces pueda montar una cafetería para ofrecer otros productos.
texts.en:
José Rodrigo
Advisor: Marta Lucía
Date: December 22, 2010

José Rodrigo knows perfectly well what it means to work on the street.  Twenty-five years ago he started his adventure as an entrepreneur by selling sweets on the streets of Medllín, Colombia.  This was his only work option.  The lack of opportunities obliged him to be an independent worker.

Although José Rodrigo has known how to survive on this business path in the streets, it is not easy.  External factors like the climate, the competition, and other adversities that he faces every day make it difficult.

This hard-worker now needs financial assistance to stock his business more.  He will buy things like sweets, cookies, candy, and gum.  Those items generate a daily household income.

As a great visionary, José Rodrigo dreams of having his own place in the future.  In addition to selling sweets, he would be able to set up a cafe in order to sell other products.

loans.use: To buy supplies

loans.name: Luxurious Group

texts.en: Chello S.'s main source of income comes from selling fish in her community. She is 22 years old, married and has a small child. They are from the village of Looc Libertad, Sapang Dalaga, Mis. Occ. Chello has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Chello joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Chello is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. Chello is the leader of a three member group accessing a loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Luxurious". About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a 41-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and a ready-to-wear clothing business. She lives in Bago City in the province of Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004, and she has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 9000 PHP.

Helen is borrowing 10,000 PHP to fund her business operations. This will be her eleventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Helen aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than 1 USD a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Idekel 1 & 2 Group

texts.es:
Gloria pertenece al grupo Idekel 1 & 2, nombre tomado de la Biblia, ya que es un grupo formado por base cristiana, cada uno de ellos días a días realizan sus actividades de negocios en la ciudad de Los Alcarrizos, ya sean con negocios establecidos en sus propias viviendas y/o locales,  o de manera ambulante. Se dedican mayormente a la venta de Ropa, Calzados, Accesorios, cosméticos, alimentos, entre otros productos misceláneos. 
 
Gloria posee una familia conformada por sus dos hijos  y su esposo. Sus hijos asisten a la escuela, y sus planes como familia, los lleva a trabajar y planificar un futuro mejor, donde sus hijos puedan completar su educación superior y su negocio pueda prosperar y ser un negocio familiar. 

El negocio de Gloria es la venta de calzado, lleva ya alrededor de 4 años, el cual inicio vendido zapatos por catalogo. Gloria ha tomado ya su 6to. prestamos con Esperanza Internacional, y se siente muy agradecida por que con los préstamos a podido avanzar y poder invertir en su negocio. Este nuevo préstamo será invertido en la compra de calzados para mujeres, de diferentes estilos, colores y tamaños. 

Su historia representa a los demás miembros de su grupo y a los clientes de Esperanza, tanto los haitianos (quienes en su mayoría ha emigrado hacia la República Dominicana desde Haití, algunos de ellos recientemente) y los dominicanos, quienes por lo general viven en comunidades muy pobres, esta zona, como muchas otras zonas de escasos recursos en la República Dominicana, carecen de agua potable y energía eléctrica constante.
texts.en:
Gloria is a member of the 'Idekel 1 & 2” group.  The name is taken from the Bible since this is a group with a Christian base.  Every day, each member of the group carries out their business activities in the town of Los Alcarrizos.  Some have their own businesses established in their own homes and / or premises, while others do not sell from a fixed location.  Most of the group's members sell clothes, shoes, accessories, cosmetics, food and other miscellaneous products.

Gloria's family consists of her two children and her husband.  Her children go to school.  Gloria  works for her family and plans a better future where her children can complete their higher education and her business can prosper and become a family business.

Gloria's business is selling shoes and she has been in the business for around 4 years.  She started out selling shoes from a catalog.  This is Gloria's 6th loan from Esperanza Internacional and she feels very grateful because her previous loans have enabled her to make progress and invest in her business.  She will invest this new loan in buying women's shoes in different styles, colors and sizes.

Gloria's story is representative of the other members of her group and Esperanza's clients in general, both the Haitians (who mainly emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti, some of them recently) and the Dominicans.  They generally live in very poor communities.  This area, like many other poor areas in the Dominican Republic, lacks a reliable supply of drinking water and electricity.

loans.use: To buy shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Additonal assorted utensils - pans, bowls, bucket, rubbers etc. in larger quantities

loans.name: Marmol

texts.es:
Marmol de 64 años, es un hombre trabajador que con esfuerzo y dedicación ha podido tener su negocio ambulante de atciculos y productos de uso personal. 

Comenzó a vender productos de uso personal en las calles, poco a poco con esfuerzo a podido tener una economía estable, trabaja desde las 06h00am hasta las 19h00pm todos los días. Para seguir trabajando con la venta de productos necesita comprar con el préstamo pasta de dientes, papel higiénico etc. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa y incrementar su negocio.
texts.en:
64 year-old Marmol is a hard-working man who, through a lot of hard work and commitment, has been able to set up his own business selling personal care products as an itinerant street trader.

Marmol started selling personal care products in the streets.  With effort, he gradually managed to become financially stable.  He works from 6.00am to 7.00pm every day.  In order to continue selling his products, he needs to use his loan to buy toothpaste, toilet paper, etc.  In the future, he would like to finish building his home and increase his business.

loans.use: to buy toilet paper, accessories and articles

loans.name: Bonefance

texts.en:
Bonefance would like a loan to buy  sugar, rice, soap and bicycle spare parts for resale. 

He is a retailer and has been in business for four years.

Bonefance desires to educate his children and improve his family’s standard of living.

He has challenges in restocking his shop due to limited funds. 

His dream is to become a wholesale trader.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, soap and bicycle spare parts for resale

loans.name: Chu

texts.en:
L. Chu Thị, age 47, lives in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. To make a living, L. raises livestock, specifically cattle, to offer for sale. L. has been engaged in this business for over 18 years and earns approximately 2.800.000 VND a month from these activities. She and her husband have one school-aged child.  
  
In 2008, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. L. has successfully repaid her most recent previous loan of 8.288.000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. L. is now requesting a new loan of 8.288.000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA. L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the borrower's business.
 
About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in the rural areas of Hanoi and the northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

-----------------------

L. Chu Thị (20209040012) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 1 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, L. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 18 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 2.800.000 VND một tháng.
 
Vào 2008, L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  L. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác.  Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  L. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.
 
Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies for her cattle

loans.name: El Renacer 5 Group

texts.en:
Timoteo lives in the rural area surrounding Hato Mayor. In this area the economy is centered around agriculture and it is one of the poorest communities around the main city of the Dominican Republic. Timoteo and his group of five entrepreneurs are taking loans for their businesses. They are sellers of many products such as clothing, shoes, groceries and communication products. This group is named El Renacer (Reborn) 5.
Timoteo requires a loan to buy groceries. He runs a grocery stall, selling in the street and to neighbors. He will buy different products such as candies, snack potatoes, chocolate bars, lollipops, etc. He has taken six previous loans since starting with his first loan from Esperanza three years ago. He started his business after he stopped working for other people and decided to start his own business. Timoteo's dreams for his future are to have his own house, raise his only child and buy a vehicle. He and his group are thankful for your support!
The woman shown inset was not available when the group met to take this picture.

loans.use: to buy groceries.

loans.name: Tchilalo

texts.fr: Agée de 31 ans à un agent de sécurité privé, Mme K. est mère de 02 enfants. Elle achète des ustensiles de cuisine au grand marché de Lomé et revend de manière ambulante à  la population depuis 2009.elle va partout où le besoins se fait ressentir. Ce premier crédit lui permettra de louer un local  si possible vu  l’importance des demandes et augmenter son stock.
texts.en: Ms. Kakon, aged 31, is [married] to a private security guard and is the mother of two children. She buys kitchen utensils at the Grand Market of Lomé and has been selling them door-to-door to people since 2009. She goes wherever there is a need. This initial loan will enable her to rent a spot, if possible, given the significance of the demand, and to increase her inventory of goods.

loans.use: to buy kitchen utensils

loans.name: Martha Cecilia

texts.es:
Martha Cecilia tiene 39 años, es soltera  vive  con los padres en  el Cantón Chillanes Provincia de Bolívar.

Los miembros de la V.R.C.  COOPERATIVA Patrón San Miguel se encuentra ubicada en el recinto Pailaloma a 60 minutos de la oficina pertenece al Cantón Chillanes, esta ventanilla de 13 miembros se dedica a las labores agrícolas de cultivos de maíz, papas y trigo.

Martha se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, papas y trigo, los productos los compra en  Chillanes y en San Pablo cada fin de mes y los vende en la feria de los domingos en Chillanes.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos para los cultivos además de fertilizantes y abonos.  Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades y aumentar la producción. Enfrentar desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es algun dia comprar ganado para dedicarse a la cianza y venta de estos.

Le gustar pasar tiempo con la familia.
texts.en:
Martha Cecilia is 39 years old, single and lives with her parents in Chillanes Canton, Bolívar Province.

The “Patrón San Miguel” (Patron Saint Michael) communal bank’s members are located in Pailaloma Recinto, 60 minutes from the office.  It belongs to Chillanes Canton.  This communal bank has 13 members dedicated to corn, potato and wheat farming.

Martha is a corn, potato and wheat farmer.  She buys her supplies in Chillanes and in San Pablo at the end of each month and her sales take place during the Sunday market in Chillanes.

She is asking for the loan to buy some farming supplies in addition to fertilizer and manure.  Support from the loan will help her economically to meet her needs and increase production.  The challenges she faces are infestations, illnesses and weather variations.  Her dream is to buy livestock some day to go into animal raising.

She enjoys spending time with her family.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies, fertilizer and manure.

loans.name: Gocha

texts.en:
Gocha is a farmer from the village of Kvitiri, Tskaltubo District, West Georgia. He lives with his wife Ella, a 21-year-old son, and a 17-year-old daughter. 

The only source of income for the family is agriculture. In particular, they have small dairy farm of two cows, whose milk is used for cheese production. Gocha and Ella sell the cheese at a local open market. The family also owns three greenhouses, where they grow cucumbers. Harvested cucumbers are also sold on the open market by the family members. 

With the requested loan Gocha plans to purchase cucumber seeds and fertilizer. After fertilizing the land, the quality and quantity of the harvest will increase and the family will be able to earn more. An increase in their income will enable Gocha and Ella to start renovating their house, which is old and needs some repair. The family will enjoy better living conditions in their renovated house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and cucumbers seeds

loans.name: Azucena

texts.en:
Azucena is 57 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 9 children. 

Azucena is a tailor. She sews office & school uniforms. She has had this business for 20 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy materials needed for sewing.

Azucena is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Azucena hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy materials needed for sewing.

loans.name: Lucho

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “EL DIAMANTE DE URUBAMBA”; el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito de Urubamba en la Provincia de Urubamba y Departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Lucho; el socio tiene 38 años de edad, el socio es conviviente, y tiene 1 hijo de 12 años de edad; el socio trabaja en la institución Arariwa en las oficinas de Urubamba, el socio también alterna su trabajo y cuando tiene un tiempo libre el socio se dedica a la crianza de animales menores, el compra animales menores tales como cuyes, chanchos, pollos, cerdos, los cría engorda llegan a la madurez los reproduce y los vende, el socio desea poder aumentar el número de animales que tiene para hacer una pequeña granja y vender al por mayor. El socio solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de animales menores para la venta.

El socio agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
Lucho, 38, is a member of the “El Diamante de Urubamba” (Urubamba’s Diamond) communal bank located in Urubamba District, Cusco Province and Department.

He has a spouse and a 12-year-old son.   He works for Asociación Arariwa’s Urubamba office.  He also has another occupation: when he has free time he raises small farm animals.  He buys such animals as guinea pigs, pigs and chickens that he raises and when they reach maturity he breeds them and then sells them.  He’d like to increase the number of animals he has to start a small farm and be a wholesaler.  He is asking for the loan to buy small farm animals to sell.

He is grateful for the support he will be granted and commits to make his installment payments in a disciplined way.

loans.use: to buy small farm animals to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a married parent with ten children. She runs a clothing business in the Philippines and works hard to support her family. She earns additional income from raising pigs.  Helen has been sustaining her business activities with the help of her twelve past loans from NWTF. 

Helen is requesting an 18,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more clothing to sell. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Salom

texts.en:
Salom is an active and hardworking man. He is married and the father of three children. His wife is a housewife. Salom is engaged in a farming business and he has been in this business for 10 years. His land is located two km from his house and he easily visits his land every day. He stays there from early morning until evening. Salom would like to get a loan of 5,000 TJS for purchasing seeds, mineral fertilizers, fuel and lubricants for his fruit garden and to pay his worker.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seeds, mineral fertilizers, fuel and lubricants and to pay his worker

loans.name: Yamileth Del Rosario

texts.es: La señora Yamileth, es habitante del municipio de Ticuantepe, junto a su pequeño hijos, los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones  de vida  , con el primer financiamiento logro realizar mejorías en la parte delantera de la vivienda , ahora quiere realizar una división , ya que actualmente lo que divide entre la sala y el cuarto son sabanas y no goza de privacidad , doña Yamileth , labora en una casa privada , el cual su salario no le permite realizar de una sola vez compra de  materiales de construcción , agrade Afodenic que atrávez de los fondo Kiva  personas de bajos recursos  puedan logran sus sueños de tener una vivienda justa .
texts.en: Mrs. Yamileth lives in the town of Ticuantepe with her young children and her plans are to improve their living conditions.  With the first loan she received she was able to make improvements to the front part of her house.  Now she wants to build a wall to divide the living room and bedrom, since there is only a sheet separating the two which does not allow for privacy.  Yamileth works in a private house and her salary is not enough for her to buy the construction materials all at once.  She is grateful to Afodenic for the Kiva fund which helps low-income earners realize their dreams and have a dignified dwelling.

loans.use: To buy construction materials.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 49 years old and married with five children. She is a farmer who lives with her family in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Her eldest child is 24 years old. Mary Jane helps her husband till their land and plant rice crops and she also helps keep the farm free of weeds and pests. She rents a stall at the market to sell their harvest and earns about 10,000 PHP each month. 

Mary Jane is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizer, seed and insecticides. In the future, she hopes to send all her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, seed, and insecticide

loans.name: Surma's Group

texts.en:
Surma is the leader of this group. She is 57 and unfortunately, she is a widow. She has raised two sons and a daughter. The daughter is married and lives separately with her family, the first son works in construction, and the younger son works in a car repairing center. Four years ago with an initial investment of 10000 KGS, Surma opened a grocery store. She earns about 3000 KGS per month. With the profits gained from the business, Surma was able to purchase three cows and ten sheep. She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase beverages, macaroni, and oil, etc. In the future, she is planning to start building a house for her sons.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase beverages, macaroni, and oil.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is 61 years old and lives in Marapong, Sibutad. She is a widow with 2 children.

Thelma has a shop that sells assorted grocery items and other dry goods. She has had this business for 4 years. She requested a loan of 7,000 PHP for her granddaughter's tuition fee.

Thelma has been a member of PMPC for 2 years.

loans.use: to pay for her granddaughter's tuition fee

loans.name: Diolita

texts.en:
Diolita is 41 years old and married with eleven children. She works hard to provide for her family. 
Diolita runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a loan of 18,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to purchase additional cases of soft drinks and gallons of coconut wine.
Diolita has borrowed and paid back nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her sari-sari store for five years and also earns an income from buying rice.
Diolita aspires to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional cases of soft drinks and gallons of coconut wine to sell.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna lives in the peaceful village of Enrile, Cagayan. Despite her age, she established a retail store selling both food and daily used products such as milk, eggs, biscuits, soap and shampoo to the people in her village. She had been in this business for almost five years. She needs to generate an income to pay for bills such as electric, water and daily meals. 

Edna is now 56-years-old, married and has five grown children. Sometimes they help her financially but she doesn't want to rely on their remittances. 

She is now requesting a loan of P50,000 to buy soft drinks, canned goods, eggs, biscuits and sugars to sell in her store. She would like to improve her sales to make her financially stable.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, canned goods, eggs, biscuits and sugars to sell in her store.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 31 years old and lives in the town of Kamuli in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past nine years, Mariam has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells different kinds of household supplies. 

To help expand her business, Mariam is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to purchase rice and beans. Her loan will help Mariam generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Mariam hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a hardware business. 

Mariam is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mariam who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase rice and beans

loans.name: Jose Nelson

texts.es:
José, ha realizado su inversión con el préstamo anterior, tuvo muy buenos resultados, por eso está motivado para aumentar la mercadería, actualmente comprara concentrado para las gallinas, además comprara abono para preparar la siembra de la temporada.
El préstamo anterior le ayudo para mantener el equilibrio necesario y atender a los clientes, con la venta de gallinas y de granos básicos.
texts.en:
José made an investment with a previous loan and had very good results. That is why he was motivated to increase his merchandise. At present he will buy concentrated feed for his hens. He will also buy fertilizer to prepare for the planting season. 

The previous loan helped him to maintain the necessary balance and attend to his customers when selling hens and basic grains.

loans.use: to buy concentrated feed for his hens.

loans.name: Etelvina

texts.es:
La señora Etelevina  es casada y vive con su esposo Joaquin,  quienes desde muy temprano en la mañana se levantan para elaborar sus productos de barro, doña Etelvina desde muy joven se dedica a la elaboración y venta de artesanía, vende adornos, flores, ollas, jarrones, todo elaborado de barro, su esposo se encarga en la decoración de los utensilios, los pinta y les hace diseños, en su casa todos los que han vivido con ella han aprendido el oficio.
Etelvina utilizara el credito para comprar tierra, barro, leña y pintura.
se aproxima la navidad y este tipo de artesanias se venden bastante y desea estar preparada para satisfacer las exigencias de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Etelvina is married and lives with her husband, Joaquín.  They rise very early in the morning to make their clay objects.  Etelvina has been making clay crafts like decorations, flowers, pots, jugs, etc and her husband decorates them; he paints them and makes designs on them.  Everyone who has lived with them in their house has learned this occupation.

Etelvina will use the loan to buy soil, clay, firewood and paint.  Christmas is approaching and these kinds of crafts sell quite a bit and she wants to be prepared to meet customer demand.

loans.use: to buy soil, clay, firewood and paint.

loans.name: Elmer Joel

texts.es: Elmer, de 28 años de edad,de oficio agricultor. Agradece mucho el apoyo brindado por medio del primer prestamo Kiva que obtuvo el cual utilizo para sembrar 1 manzana de tomtates, de los cuales vendio todo el plantio fue muy bueno porque logro pagar gastos qu tenia,pudo pagar el prestamo y hacer algunas mejoras en su hogar. Ahora se acerca  un nuevo ciclo productivo muy bueno para las siembras de hortalizas y el esta solicitando un segundo credito Kiva para siembra de tomates,comprar de insumos,abonos fertilizantes y pago de mano de obra.Pues el desea seguir trabajndo fuerte y terminar de construir su vivienda.
texts.en: Elmer, 28, is a farmer. He is very thankful for the support given to him via his first Kiva loan, which he used to plant a block of tomatoes which he then sold. The planting went very well because he was able to cover his expenses, pay back the loan and make some improvements to his house. Now that it's getting close to another good planting season he is asking for a second Kiva loan to plant tomatoes, buy agricultural inputs like fertilizers and manure, and pay laborers. He wants to keep working hard and finish building his home.

loans.use: to harvest his tomatoes.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is 27 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 
Alma provides motorela (three-wheeled vehicle powered by motorcycle) or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver. She has run this business for five years. She has requested a loan of 9,000 PHP to buy tools and pay for gasoline to run the service.
Alma has been a member of Kiva partner HSPFI since 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for gasoline to run the service.

loans.name: Sherlita

texts.en:
Sherlita is 51 years old and married with one child.

Sherlita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a beauty products retail business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional beauty products to sell.

Sherlita has borrowed and repaid twenty-eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the beauty products retail business for twelve years and also earns an income from raising pigs and from a sari-sari (variety) store.

Sherlita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Gabina

texts.en:
Gabina is a 63-year-old married woman with 5 children. She runs a sari-sari store business in Trinidad, Bohol. Gabina sells spices, canned goods, soy sauce, vinegar and other various items. Gabina works hard to sustain her family and send her children to school.

Gabina has requested this loan to buy more items to sell such as canned goods, packed noodles, shampoo and soap. Gabina hopes to expand her store in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as canned goods, packed noodles, shampoo and soap.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 

Eugenia has a food shop, or sari-sari store, that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for 10,000 PHP to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Eugenia has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Eugenia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Tunta's Group

texts.en:
Tunta, 30, lives in a rural area of the Mongkul Borey district of Banteay Meanchey province, Cambodia. She has one daughter, who is dependent on her and still in school. Rice farming is the main source of the family’s income. Tunta has been a rice farmer for four years. To add more income for the family, her husband also works for others in the local area, for a fee. Their current business brings in approximately 20,000 KHR per day, and they can save about 10,000 KHR each day after daily living expenses.
  
Tunta has been a member of Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for five loan cycles, and she completely paid back the previous loans, which improved her family's livelihood. Now she and her group member are requesting a loan of 200,000 KHR each with VisionFund. As leader, Tunta is going to use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to grow her rice fruitfully and timely, so as to improve her standard of living and keep her daughter in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Jipange Group

texts.en:
